Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Iminium Salts as Potential Water Oxidation Catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Ksenija Glusac of Bowling Green State University is supported by the Chemical Catalysis (CAT) Program in the Division of Chemistry to explore iminium ions and their pseudobase derivatives as potential catalysts for the oxidation of water to molecular oxygen. The proposed water-oxidation catalytic cycle consists of four steps. Iminium ions are first reacted with water to form the pseudobases. This is followed with the conversion of the pseudobases to the corresponding alkoxyl radicals via proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET). The alkoxyl radicals are then combined in pairs to produce peroxide derivatives, which subsequently undergo two-electron oxidation to release oxygen and recover the iminium ions. Each step will be studied with appropriately selected model compounds. Cyclic voltammetry, femtosecond pump-probe measurements, as well as electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy will be used to follow the steps of the scheme, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations will be conducted to inform the proposed experiments.

The overarching goal of the proposal is to develop a purely organic catalyst to facilitate the splitting of water to produce oxygen and hydrogen fuel in a solar fuel cell setup. If successful it will contribute significantly to the development of renewable energy sources and hence to energy sustainability. In addition to several teaching and training activities, the educational broader impacts include the development of a summer program that covers lectures, discussions, seminars and student presentations. The emphasis of the program is on mentoring of female and minority undergraduate students to encourage them to consider graduate education and help them achieve academic excellence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our main goal was to study catalysts for oxidation of water to oxygen. In general, catalysis of the oxygen evolution reaction represents a great challenge for chemists because it involves multiple electron-transfer processes that need to be coupled with bond-forming and bond-breaking steps. The catalysts that are most efficient are often made of noble-metals, which are expensive and toxic. With the support from NSF, we investigated the inexpensive alternative catalysts that are made of earth-abundant elements, such as C, H, N and O.

 

We studied a large number of model compounds that contain carbon and nitrogen atoms and that belong to a class of cationic compounds called iminium ions. Our hypothesis was that iminium ions have the correct functionality for catalysis because they can reversible react with oxygen intermediates and undergo electrochemical oxidation. Our study led to a discovery of first organic catalyst capable of electrocatalytic water oxidation and resulted in the development of a structure-property relationship which can be used to design future, more efficient catalysts.

 

While not directly related to the proposed work, our research lead to an unexpected discovery of photobases, compounds that become exceptionally strong bases after they absorb light. This work is expected to have a strong impact on the development of a new class of photo-active catalysts for photo-polymerization reactions and other chemical transformations of interest.

 

This work contributes to a general scientific effort towards energy storage applications. Electrocatalytic water oxidation represents a fundamental process that occurs in a number of devices, such as photoelectrochemical water splitting cells, fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Our group trains future scientists that are aware of advantages and challenges associated with the field of energy storage. The project resulted in 16 publications. In addition, the funds were used to train one postdoctoral fellow (Yang Xin), 3 graduate students (Yun Xie, Marija Zoric and Stefan Ilic) and 4 undergraduate students (Jelena Stevanovic, Sanja Skaro, Milena Milenkovic, Vuk Vukovic). The results of the research were presented at a number of conferences and departmental seminars (more than 30 lectures and posters presented by the PI and graduate students).

 

 


Last Modified: 02/17/2018
Modified by: Ksenija D Glusac
